intro: Convolvulus tricolor subvar. pseudotricolor, commonly known as the three-color morning glory, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and western Asia. It is characterized by its trifoliate leaves and vibrant, trumpet-shaped flowers that display three distinct colors—typically red, yellow, and white. The plant thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, often growing as a climbing or trailing vine. Its flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. The subspecies pseudotricolor is distinguished by its more pronounced color separation compared to the typical Convolvulus tricolor.
